answers.answer: My sister had a home birth and said it was absolutely amazing for her. My only worry is if there is a problem with my baby. When I had my second son in hospital and he needed immediate medical intervention using all sorts of equipment as he couldnt breathe. If I were at home I dread to think wat could have happened. Definitely talk it through with ur doc if its something u wanna do

I've had two wonderful home-births! Your first step is to find a midwife that you enjoy and trust. She'll guide you through everything you need as your pregnancy progresses. Good luck! Start reading Ina May's Guide to Childbirth. It made up my mind and my family's too. My mom and I watched The Business of Being Born. That helped explain it too.

Thanks ladies. I do worry about if something happens with the baby but I live really close to the hospital. I am going to be talk a midwife this week. I really want my family to be on board. The business of being born where would I find that?

I have a friend who Is a midwife For home and natural births. She had All five of her kids At home and She recommends It to Everyone She meets That Is pregnant lol.  I'm honestly a chicken So I Don't feel Like I can do That as much as I'd love to be able to. But I get bad anxiety So I think It would stress me out. Just talk to Some midwives, weigh out All The pros n cons and talk with Ur family about It. But It's your baby and your body So ultimately It's your decision.:)

I no alot of people who have had wonderful home births.....but also its a little scary because if something went wrong you would have to rush to the hospital.... They do have birthing centers that are normally almost connected to the hospital or across the street so that you have the at home experience with a midwife in a normal bed but if anything happened the hospital is right there

"Close" to a hospital isn't good enough.  If something goes really wrong,  it doesn't matter if you're 8 minutes from the hospital or 80 miles.  If you're not IN the hospital if your uterus ruptures,  or your baby's chord is suddenly clamped,  or your baby flips to breech during delivery and delivers the entire body but the head gets stuck,  8 minutes is death.I do agree that midwives are great,  and going natural is really great,  but do it in a hospital where you can save your baby's life if need be.

I was going to do a home birth but they don't take insurance and I couldn't afford to pay our of pocket.  But a midwife is trained to take care of emergencies if they happen.  You will be in good hands.

I really wanted to do this but my area is in the desert so its hard to get this as a reality. I wanted to do a water birth at the hospital but they don't practice it. The thing I've heard is to make sure everything is sanitary and you are with someone who can assist in an emergency. People in the older days had kids at home all the time.
I'm going natural this time around and was told to slow my body to do its job instead of tensing up and stressing.

Hospitals are not always safer for you or your baby. A good book to have sceptical family read is The Home Birth Advantage, written by a doctor. I had my first baby at home with a midwife and plan the same this time

Hospitals are better, otherwise midwives wouldn't say if things go badly we're this close to the hospital.  They'd say if things go badly in the hospital and your baby is suddenly in real danger,  don't fear,  we'll send you home to finish up.Statistics are confusing.  I don't doubt,  that home births usually have good outcomes - because the moms and midwives who choose that path start with perfectly healthy babies and mothers.  And hospital births often have mothers who have had extremely unhealthy pregnancies,  the babies are in danger,  they are in preterm labor,  they have preeclampsia or placenta previa,  etc.  Those pregnancies don't factor into the home births,  they factor only into hospital birth numbers.Same reason that private schools do so much better than public schools.  Because they can pick and choose the best students.So.  If you completely randomly assigned pregnant women to either a home birth or a hospital birth,  and after 1000 births in each random category (and didn't allow the home birth moms to change their minds during labor or if the baby were dying),  you had to do a home birth or hospital birth through to the end,  the statistics would finally teach us what most intuitively know - home births are much much more dangerous than hospital births.As lovely as home births can be,  if they turn out well.

I think she was asking about home birth experiences not why she shouldn't have one. It sounds like she already has her mind made up to stay home.  Yes not everyone is meant to deliver at home. That's why high risk people go to the hospital.  If she is not high risk she is a good candidate to stay home

Thanks ladies!! I do have my mind made up that I want a home birth and I am going to talk to a midwife as well as my ob. I just believe the risk can be the same no matter where I have my baby. There is just as many cons to a hospital birth as there is to me having a home birth. Also I have been reading alot online that tells me not bring my sick child to the hospital/er and take them to their pediatician they why would I want to have my healthy baby in a hospital. I believe theu get more exposure to more germs there than in my home.

The risk is not the same,  Martha.  The risk for a home birth leaves you stranded if your baby is suddenly unable to have oxygen,  or if you're suddenly bleeding to death.You will very most likely be lucky,   because you are healthy and courageous,  and it's very likely your baby and you will be fine.But if something goes wrong in the last minutes,  this could end tragically.Honestly,  you could probably back up in your car without looking behind you and it would usually be perfectly fine.  But people do know to look behind their car before backing up.Best wishes with your birth.
http://mana.org/index.php?q=blog/home-birth-safety-outcomes

martha, I'm in to statistics,  and studies,  and cause and effect.Did you read the study?  I think the study results couldn't agree with me more.First, it noted that the sample was women with excellent pregnancies,  and very healthy babies who chose to labor at home.  So they've already spooned off,  for the purposes of this study,   any women who were predicted to need any medical interventions at all.  There were no placenta previas,  no preeclampsia patients,  no gestational diabetes,  no small pelvic structure patients,  no IGR babies,  no breech or transverse presentations,  etc.  Only ones who can expect a very smooth labor and healthy outcome,  needing no assistance.  Those women would also have fared well if they gave birth in the back of a cab.Of those healthy women, just over 10% had to be transferred to a hospital during labor due to complications.  What would have happened to those 10% had there not been a hospital to take care of a problem birth?  I think we know.  Not a great outcome.When you do a scientific study,  it's imperative that you look at your sample,  and make SURE it's random.You can't make any inferences about the safety of a birth practice,  if you've purposely spooned off only very healthy women to participate.  Of course they won't need interventions,  that's completely expected.This study,  says nothing.  It only tells you that the healthiest moms going into labor probably will need the fewest interventions.  And we all know that.

Martha a midwife brings all the stuff neccessary in case an emergency should  you need it.  ie baby needs o2.  I went through all of that when I was going to do a home birth. Make sure you get a good midwife there is different certifications out there.  I think the best obe you can get is the certified nurse midwife or CNM.  There is also ones that are certified midwives but they have different certifications.

You can have your baby wherever Way you please but for you and your baby but for you to try to discourage me from having my baby at home because you're uncomfortable With it is ridiculous. I get your opinion but for you to keep stating the same thing over and over and over again is driving me crazy. You have no fact to back it up. people all over the world have home births and are perfectly fine. in fact if there was never home birth none of us would be here today. reasons I want to have a home birth is I wanted to be a personal experience I don't want to have to see five different doctors all different types of people be hooked up to machines. and 46% of United States hospital birth end up in Ceaseran because of medications the doctor give you. Please do not comment if you are not going to accept other peoples option because at the end if the day the decision is mine and mine alone.

Usually,  they are fine,  and I will continue to comment,  thanks.I do have facts.  I was a labor companion in a hospital a few years ago and a very healthy,  fit woman was brought in by ambulance with her midwife.  The baby had turned breech during labor,  and the body could be delivered, but not the head.  The baby was dead by the time the ambulance arrived to take her to the hospital.I have a friend who delivered in a hospital and had placenta accrecia and nearly died from blood loss.  Thank God she was in the hospital,  because at home she would certainly have died.Most babies do make it,  who are delivered outside of medical facilities,  that's true.And I know you don't want to hear that,  and for some reason you think you can tell people not to post on this forum,  but it's a public forum and this message needs to get out.You only want to hear positive things about your choice,  which isn't the way to learn.Best wishes with your delivery.  I hope you're not one of the 10% who has to get rushed to the hospital in labor at home,  and if you are,  I hope everything goes well.

Final thought,  the big picture here with MedHelp.These aren't private discussions.  MANY more people read these threads,  and rely on getting good information, than post here.  This forum is huge,  and has a huge readership of both members and non members.MedHelp has a reputation for being a reliable resource for good information -  and when something is posted as "fact" and doesn't get corrected,  readers believe it.The fact is,  home births are statistically not safer than hospital births.  No where near as safe.When they go perfectly they are wonderful,  and empowering,  and gentler than hospital births,  and a lovely memory.  So it's something to consider.But while considering home vs. hospital births,  mothers shouldn't be given the incorrect information that all things being equal,  home births are safer.  Because they aren't.And medhelp's forums should reflect that fact.

question: Pregnant with my first child and I want to have a home birth. I don't know anyone who has had one and would love some advice. My boyfriend is completely supportive but our family seem to be a bit freaked out by it. I don't know what to do.
title: Home Birth
